Award.AwardTitle: DC: Medium: Collaborative Research: Data Intensive Computing: Scalable, Social Data Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Analysts in all areas of human knowledge, from science and engineering
to economics, social science and journalism are drowning in data. The
proliferation of digital information requires tools and techniques for
exploring, analyzing and communicating data in a manner that scales as
both the data and the organizations analyzing it grow in
size. Throughout the data life-cycle, sensemaking is often a
collaborative process. As different analysts each contribute to data
acquisition, cleaning, analysis, and interpretation they contribute
contextual knowledge that deepens understanding. Analysts may disagree
on how to interpret data, but then work together to reach
consensus. Many data sets are so large that thorough exploration by a
single person is unlikely. In short, social cognition plays a critical
role in the process of scalable data analysis. New analysis tools that
address human cognitive characteristics, social interaction and data
analytics in an integrated fashion can improve our ability to turn
data into knowledge.

Scalable data analysis requires social interaction and therefore
social context must be embedded in data analysis tools. The goals of
this project are (1) to understand how social interaction and social
context can facilitate successful data analysis, (2) to develop models
and tools for representing and annotating data transformations,
visualizations, and social activity (e.g., textual and graphical
annotations, discussions, links, tags), and (3) to design and test
visual interfaces that leverage our tools to support collaborative
analysis practices, including data entry, transformation,
visualization, and interpretation. Central concerns include (a) a
focus on enabling social interaction throughout the data life-cycle
and (b) the use of scalable data transformation routines that can
return results in a time frame concordant with interactive,
exploratory data transformation and analysis.


Further information on this project can be found at:
http://vis.berkeley.edu/projects/scalable_social_data_analysis/

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has produced a variety of outcomes that have served to deepen our understanding of social data analysis. We have developed a variety of systems that are designed to let people (even strangers) work together in analyzing data -- including data entry and cleaning, comment-based analysis, crowdsourced analysis, email analysis, and text analysis in medical forums. This work has led to dozens of papers, some of which are already highly cited. One of the Ph.D. students supported by this grant will join the Univ. of Calgary as an Assistant Professor in 2015 and two other Ph.D. students have formed companies (Trifacta and Captricity) based on ideas that evolved from this grant.  Moreover, this grant has supported the release of open-source software tools, data sets, and teaching resources available for public use.


Over the 2010-2011 academic year we focused on building the infrastructure necessary to investigate the variety of issues that arise in social data analysis. We developed interfaces and algorithmic tools designed to support four areas of social data analysis; 1) data entry, 2) data cleanup, 3) comment-based analysis of data and 4) social analysis of email. In addition we designed graduate level courses on Interactive Data Analysis and Visualization to help train graduate students in the interdisciplinary background material from Databases, HCI, Statistics and Visualization necessary to engage in research in Scalable, Social Data Analysis.


In the 2011-2012 academic year we further developed these research directions. Specifically, we 1) extended our data transformation tools, 2) created novel network modeling and visualization tools, 3) developed new crowdsourcing mechanisms to enhance comment-based analysis, 4) devised new algorithms for email analysis, 5) developed a service for crowdsourced digitization of paper forms, and 6) designed new interactive graphical database query interfaces. We also continued the educational activities begun previously.


In the 2012-2013 academic year we advanced our research agenda in several directions. We 1) refined our crowdsourcing approach to bootstrapping comment-based analysis, 2) we extended our analysis of comment data to the domain of medical informatics, where we developed novel methods for identifying salient medical terms in patient-authored text, and 3) we expanded our research on data transformation and quality assessment by conducting semi-structured interviews with practicing data scientists, revealing numerous findings that inform our research questions and might help promote broader impacts, and 4) developed computational learning theory results underlying our graphical database query interfaces.


In the 2013-2014 we focused on completing projects and tying up loose ends. We 1) advanced our work on crowdsourcing data analysis by developing techniques for identifying redundancy and provenance in crowdsourced explanations for trends in data, 2) we expanded our work on text analysis in medical forums in two directions: (a) improved pattern-based induction approaches for performing multi-class entity extraction (in this case, discriminating between symptoms and treatments) and (b) in collaboration with an addiction specialist, performed large-scale analyses of substance abuse forums, enabling new insights into patterns of drug use and phases of addiction and withdrawal.
